issue.title: passwordHash options
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Hello everybody.
I am trying to support the passwordHash function's option with a custom cost for the salt length,
but no matter what I do besides setting the option's table to an empty {} table it always gives me this error in the console:

> [08:39:05] Resource 'loginpanel' changed, reloading and starting
> [08:39:05] Starting loginpanel
> [08:39:05] loginpanel restarted successfully
> [08:39:06] ERROR: loginpanel/sh_actions.lua:19: invalid key to 'next'

I am doing it like this:
`passwordHash(password, "bcrypt", {20,""}, passwordHashed)`
since it said an empty sting but I tried setting it to **nil** or just making the table like this: **{20}**
but I always get the same error, unless I set the table to an empty table like this: **{}**

Do I miss something or just dumb for this or is this a bug (I higly doubt this is a bug tho)?

### Steps to reproduce

`passwordHash(password, "bcrypt", {20}, passwordHashed)`
Setting the options table to anything else than **{}** (Empty table) causes this for me.

### Version

MTA:SA Server v1.5.9-release-21258
Debian

### Additional context

_No response_

### Relevant log output

_No response_

### Security Policy

- [X] I have read and understood the Security Policy and this issue is not security related.

Wiki does have some errors there. It doesn't respect mta's code. 
Try this:
```lua
passwordHash(password, 'bcrypt', {
    cost = 20
}, callback) 
```

comment.body:
Yep:
Here is the full server-sided script:
```
function performAccountRegistration(playerSource, commandName, ...)
    if ( playerSource ) then
        local args = {...}
        local parameterCount = #args

        -- Username, E-mail, Password
        if ( parameterCount < 3 ) then
            outputChatBox("Not enough arguments.", playerSource, 255,0,0)
            return
        end

        local username = args[1]

        if ( not isUsernameValid(username) ) then
            outputChatBox("The username can only contain numbers and letters!", playerSource, 255,0,0)
            return
        end

        passwordHash(args[3], "bcrypt", {20}, passwordHashed)
    end
end
addCommandHandler("createAccount", performAccountRegistration)

function isUsernameValid(username)
    if string.find(username, "[^a-zA-Z0-9]") then
        return false
    end

    return true
end

function passwordHashed(hashedPassword)
    outputChatBox("You password was successfully hashed: " ..hashedPassword, playerSource, 100,255,100)
end
```

forkee.name: mtasa-blue
forkee.description: Multi Theft Auto is a game engine that incorporates an extendable network play element into a proprietary commercial single-player game.

issue.title: DSOAL support to restore DirectSound3D (3D spatial audio) and EAX (environmental reverb)
issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

Even though [San Andreas supported DirectSound3D (3D spatial audio) and EAX 1-4 (environmental reverb)](https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Grand_Theft_Auto:_San_Andreas#Audio), both were [mostly broken since Windows Vista](https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Glossary:Sound_card#DirectSound_hardware_path).
So to restore those features, you would normally need to use a DirectSound3D wrapper like Creative ALchemy (for Creative sound cards) or DSOAL (open-source alternative for any sound card), which works in base GTA:SA, but MTA seems to be hard-coded to look for the drop-in file (dsound.dll) in System32/SysWOW64 even after [applying a registry tweak that fixes that in other games](https://www.indirectsound.com/registryIssues.html).
So to use those wrappers, we can just replace the DLL in System32/SysWOW64, but that's not recommended as it reportedly can cause system stability and app compatibility issues. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

My proposed solution is to implement [DSOAL](https://github.com/kcat/dsoal) directly into MTA or allowing to load dsound.dll from the game folder so it doesn't require replacing system DLLs.
Personally, I'd prefer it was bundled with MTA to prevent possible false positives with the anti-cheat or worse: a vulnerability via malicious dsound.dll.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

I've already tried replacing the system DLLs, which works, as shown in this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxY_xaFrYm4

[![Lots of Melons + Dumpster](https://img.youtube.com/vi/xxY_xaFrYm4/maxresdefault.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxY_xaFrYm4 "Multi Theft Auto (San Andreas multiplayer) | DSOAL + OpenAL Soft Headphone 3D Spatial Audio + EAX 4")


It works fine so far both offline and online, but it's not something I would recommend anyone who's not familiar with this stuff.

### Additional context

- There's a small oversight in even base San Andreas [with a Creative sound card on Windows XP where the Y axis is inverted](https://youtu.be/Noa9K70OUcs) (sounds above sound like they're below and viceversa), but it can be fixed in [recent DSOAL](https://github.com/kcat/openal-soft/commit/e28937d1f6704bcdc3f0a194744905906b106cdd) by setting `reverse-y = true` in the `[game_compat]` section of alsoft.ini.
- In base San Andreas, using a wrapper can crash the game when getting on a motorcycle, unless Radio EQ is manually turned off and back in while in-game. However, I haven't noticed it happening in MTA.
- San Andreas shipped with EAX Unified (eax.dll) 4.0.0.1, so you could consider [updating it to 4.0.1.0](https://www.dll-files.com/eax.dll.html) (perhaps there's a better source but that one's [clean](https://www.hybrid-analysis.com/sample/d5b28eb97a5ab0cb2aad827b8ce9a4e6889e93501a759fe3b60e890cc02658a1) and works fine so far, tho I admit I don't know the changes from the previous version but I'd guess it fixes some minor issues)
- I've attached the files I use, or you can follow [these instructions](https://airtable.com/shrtTsUtiAJQ7wFGI/tblNOTdmp5nHXfFGU/viwjDPuKOjBnIQunv/recFdL9mEaMB6Lkst) to install from the official download location directly, or compile DSOAL (dsound.dll) and OpenAL Soft (dsoal-aldrv.dll), of course.
[MTA-DSOAL.zip](https://github.com/multitheftauto/mtasa-blue/files/9198997/MTA-DSOAL.zip)

### Security Policy

- [x] I have read and understood the Security Policy and this issue is not about a cheat or security vulnerability.

comment.body: Interesting stuff! But let’s keep this MTA related

comment.body:
... what in the absolute hell has GP4 to do with GTA?
And what has the directplay server to do with graphics/audio rendering? I really really don't think that a component used all across dozens of games would handle anything but network stuff. 

> I know that running executables as admin tends to set the working folder to the system one instead of the executable's

First time I hear about this (even though there are [exceptions](https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/issues/7062#issuecomment-664728705) for certain built-in applications)

> I'm not sure how one would go about doing either method, as they'd both probably need some Windows trick, game source code modification or a reverse-engineered hack.

Be it as it may, it's pretty easy actually? Just hex edit `dsound.dll` inside the executable or its libraries to some other name (and if you find none, then they are probably using CLSID which means you can play with registry entries).

issue.title: DSOAL support to restore DirectSound3D (3D spatial audio) and EAX (environmental reverb)
issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

Even though [San Andreas supported DirectSound3D (3D spatial audio) and EAX 1-4 (environmental reverb)](https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Grand_Theft_Auto:_San_Andreas#Audio), both were [mostly broken since Windows Vista](https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Glossary:Sound_card#DirectSound_hardware_path).
So to restore those features, you would normally need to use a DirectSound3D wrapper like Creative ALchemy (for Creative sound cards) or DSOAL (open-source alternative for any sound card), which works in base GTA:SA, but MTA seems to be hard-coded to look for the drop-in file (dsound.dll) in System32/SysWOW64 even after [applying a registry tweak that fixes that in other games](https://www.indirectsound.com/registryIssues.html).
So to use those wrappers, we can just replace the DLL in System32/SysWOW64, but that's not recommended as it reportedly can cause system stability and app compatibility issues. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

My proposed solution is to implement [DSOAL](https://github.com/kcat/dsoal) directly into MTA or allowing to load dsound.dll from the game folder so it doesn't require replacing system DLLs.
Personally, I'd prefer it was bundled with MTA to prevent possible false positives with the anti-cheat or worse: a vulnerability via malicious dsound.dll.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

I've already tried replacing the system DLLs, which works, as shown in this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxY_xaFrYm4

[![Lots of Melons + Dumpster](https://img.youtube.com/vi/xxY_xaFrYm4/maxresdefault.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxY_xaFrYm4 "Multi Theft Auto (San Andreas multiplayer) | DSOAL + OpenAL Soft Headphone 3D Spatial Audio + EAX 4")

- There's a small oversight in even base San Andreas [with a Creative sound card on Windows XP where the Y axis is inverted](https://youtu.be/Noa9K70OUcs) (sounds above sound like they're below and viceversa), but it can be fixed in [recent DSOAL](https://github.com/kcat/openal-soft/commit/e28937d1f6704bcdc3f0a194744905906b106cdd) by setting `reverse-y = true` in the `[game_compat]` section of alsoft.ini.

- I've attached the files I use, or you can follow [these instructions](https://airtable.com/shrtTsUtiAJQ7wFGI/tblNOTdmp5nHXfFGU/viwjDPuKOjBnIQunv/recFdL9mEaMB6Lkst) to install from the official download location directly, or compile DSOAL (dsound.dll) and OpenAL Soft (dsoal-aldrv.dll), of course.
[MTA-DSOAL.zip](https://github.com/multitheftauto/mtasa-blue/files/9198997/MTA-DSOAL.zip)

- [x] I have read and understood the Security Policy and this issue is not about a cheat or security vulnerability.

So EAX is enabled but you hear no reverb/3D audio?
You also need [alsoft.ini](https://www.dropbox.com/s/ntlo5cxol8uo3a7/alsoft.ini?dl=1) if it doesn't already exist in %APPDATA% (C:\Users\YOURUSERNAME\AppData\Roaming)

comment.body:
> multiplayer uses dplaysvr.exe which is in SysWOW64 folder

Oh boy, guess that explains it, but it's also a really bad sign. It probably means the only way you'll get EAX/3D audio in multiplayer is by replacing the system dsound.dll, unless you can:
- Force the game to load a copy of that exe from a different, non-protected **working folder** where you can install/load DSOAL DLLs from
- Force that exe to load dsound.dll from a non-protected folder, like maybe just forcing it to use the `Grand Prix 4/` folder so it behaves like `GP4.exe`. I know that running executables as admin tends to set the working folder to the system one instead of the executable's, but I don't think there are ways to make system executables use a different working folder, unless `CD`ing into another directory in command line, but I think the game itself handles/changes thew working folder.

I'm not sure how one would go about doing either method, as they'd both probably need some Windows trick, game source code modification or a reverse-engineered hack. 🤔

So to restore those features, you would normally need to use a DirectSound3D wrapper like Creative ALchemy (for Creative sound cards) or DSOAL (open-source alternative for any sound card), which works in base GTA:SA, but MTA seems to be hard-coded to look for the drop-in file (dsound.dll) in System32/SysWOW64 even after [applying a registry tweak that fixes that in other games](https://www.indirectsound.com/registryIssues.html).
So to use those wrappers, we can just replace the DLL in System32/SysWOW64, but that's not recommended as it reportedly can cause system stability and app compatibility issues. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

My proposed solution is to implement [DSOAL](https://github.com/kcat/dsoal) directly into MTA or allowing to load dsound.dll from the game folder so it doesn't require replacing system DLLs.
Personally, I'd prefer it was bundled with MTA to prevent possible false positives with the anti-cheat or worse: a vulnerability via malicious dsound.dll.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

I've already tried replacing the system DLLs, which works, as shown in this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxY_xaFrYm4

[![Lots of Melons + Dumpster](https://img.youtube.com/vi/xxY_xaFrYm4/maxresdefault.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xxY_xaFrYm4 "Multi Theft Auto (San Andreas multiplayer) | DSOAL + OpenAL Soft Headphone 3D Spatial Audio + EAX 4")


It works fine so far both offline and online, but it's not something I would recommend anyone who's not familiar with this stuff.

### Additional context

- There's a small oversight in even base San Andreas [with a Creative sound card on Windows XP where the Y axis is inverted](https://youtu.be/Noa9K70OUcs) (sounds above sound like they're below and viceversa), but it can be fixed in [recent DSOAL](https://github.com/kcat/openal-soft/commit/e28937d1f6704bcdc3f0a194744905906b106cdd) by setting `reverse-y = true` in the `[game_compat]` section of alsoft.ini.
- In base San Andreas, using a wrapper can crash the game when getting on a motorcycle, unless Radio EQ is manually turned off and back in while in-game. However, I haven't noticed it happening in MTA.
- San Andreas shipped with EAX Unified (eax.dll) 4.0.0.1, so you could consider [updating it to 4.0.1.0](https://www.dll-files.com/eax.dll.html) (perhaps there's a better source but that one's [clean](https://www.hybrid-analysis.com/sample/d5b28eb97a5ab0cb2aad827b8ce9a4e6889e93501a759fe3b60e890cc02658a1) and works fine so far, tho I admit I don't know the changes from the previous version but I'd guess it fixes some minor issues)
- I've attached the files I use, or you can follow [these instructions](https://airtable.com/shrtTsUtiAJQ7wFGI/tblNOTdmp5nHXfFGU/viwjDPuKOjBnIQunv/recFdL9mEaMB6Lkst) to install from the official download location directly, or compile DSOAL (dsound.dll) and OpenAL Soft (dsoal-aldrv.dll), of course.
[MTA-DSOAL.zip](https://github.com/multitheftauto/mtasa-blue/files/9198997/MTA-DSOAL.zip)

### Security Policy

- [x] I have read and understood the Security Policy and this issue is not about a cheat or security vulnerability.

comment.body:
dsound.dll is harder to replace because the original one is protected
so to disable the protection you can google "Take ownership registry key" for a reg key that adds a Take ownership option to the right click menu so that you can rename/move the original and copy the DSOAL one.

comment.body:
@gp4wonder Does multiplayer use a different executable, DLL path or working folder?
You could check where it's loading dsound.dll from in multiplayer with [API Monitor](http://www.rohitab.com/apimonitor) like [this](https://i.imgur.com/Es4WQ3Q.png).
And you can try copying the files into SysWOW64, but like I mentioned in the first post, that can cause issues with other apps so proceed at your own risk.
Otherwise, it might just be the multiplayer mode/anticheat disabling the loading of third-party/blacklisted DLLs to prevent hacks.

review.body: Further details are in dev discord. The main use of this is to fix a small bug (chance to have random, usually absurdly high playercount/slots display in Discord status)

pull_request.title: Hotfix Discord-RPC from nightly Feedbacks
pull_request.body:
Introduces patches from feedback received from people testing on the nightly build.

- Fixed random display of numbers in the state.
- Blocked the resetDiscordRichPresenceData() function if a custom Application ID is not set.
